sec.title: Keywords:

Valeriana officinalis L
.
Water decoction
Sesquiterpenoids
Iridoids
Anti-neuroinflammatory activity
ABSTRACT

Nine previously undescribed compounds including three sesquiterpenoids, three iridoids, two monoterpenoids and a furan fatty acid, along with seventeen known ones, were isolated from the water decoction of roots and rhizomes of
Valeriana officinalis L
. Structure elucidation of the twenty-six compounds were accomplished by analysis of the extensive spectroscopic data, and the absolute configurations of the nine previously undescribed ones were established by NOESY experiment and the electronic circular dichroism (ECD) simulations. Among them, β- patchoulene-8- O-β- D-glucopyranoside, 11-methoxyl-viburtinal, and protocatechuic acid showed anti-neuroinflammatory potentials by significantly inhibiting the secretion of nitric oxide (NO) on BV-2 cells upon LPS stimulation (
p <
0.001) without affecting the cell viability.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2. Results and discussion
sec.p: 3-Acetoxyl-patchouli alcohol ( 1 ) and patchouli alcohol 8- O -β -Dapiofuranosyl-(1→6)- β -D-glucopyranoside ( 2 ) were isolated as colorless oils with respective molecular formulas of C 17 H 28 O 3 and C 26 H 44 O 11 ,

Since 1 possessed the same patchouli alcohol-skeleton as 2 and 10–12 , the absolute configurations of the C-1, 3, 4, 5, 7, and 10 were then proposed as 1 R , 3 R , 4 R , 5 S , 7 R and 10 S in clue of their homology in biogenetic pathways. NOESY correlations between δ H 4.88 (1H, m, H-3) and δ H 1.12 (3H, s, H 3 -14), 0.892 (3H, d, J =6.6 Hz, H 3 -12) indicated an α -orientation of the acetoxyl moiety in 1 . The absolute configuration of 1 was then determined by comparison of its experimental ECD data with those calculated by TDDFT method (
). The experimental ECD spectrum matched well with that calculated for 1 R ,3 R ,4 R , 5 S ,7 R ,10
S -1
( Fig. 4 ). Hence, 1 was finally elucidated as (1 R ,3 R ,4 R ,5 S , 7 R ,10 S )-3-acetoxyl-patchouli alcohol.

(4 S ,7 R ,8 S ,10 R )- β -Patchoulene-8- O -β -D-glucopyranoside ( 3 ) {[α] D 25 51.0 ( c 0.20, MeOH)} isolated as a colorless oily matter, was assigned the molecular formula of C 21 H 34 O 6 by analysis of its NMR and HRESIMS ([M-H] - m/z : 381.2279, calcd 381.2282) data, indicating five indices of hydrogen deficiency. The NMR spectra ( Table 2 ) of 3 exhibited resonance peaks assignable to a skeleton of β -patchoulene (
; Yoshikawa et al., 1994), including four methyls at δ H / δ C 0.95 (3H, s, H 3 -13)/19.5, 0.94 (3H, d, J = 7.2 Hz, H 3 -12)/15.4, 0.90 (3H, s, H 3 -14)/20.1, and 1.10 (3H, s, H 3 -15)/24.0, four methylene groups at δ H / δ C 2.21 (2H, m, H 2 -2)/31.3, 2.05 (1H, m, H-3a) and 1.31 (1H, m, H-3b)/32.8, 2.31 (1H, m, H-6a) and 1.79 (1H, d, J = 17.6 Hz, H-6b)/31.0, 2.23 (1H, dd, J =13.2, 7.8 Hz, H-9a) and 1.85 (1H, dd, J = 13.2, 2.4 Hz, H-9b)/49.4, three methines at δ H / δ C 2.44 (1H, m, H-4)/43.6, 2.01 (1H, m, H-7)/52.8 and 3.95 (1H, dd, J = 8.4, 4.8 Hz, H-8)/86.5, and two olefinic carbons at δ C 144.8 (C-10) and 135.8 (C-5), as furtherly confirmed by analysis of the HSQC, 1 H 1 H COSY and HMBC data ( Table 1 , Fig. 2 ). The remaining NMR data of δ H / δ C 4.18 (1H, d, J = 7.8 > 7.0 Hz, H-1 ′ )/103.4, 3.12 (1H, t, J =8.4 Hz, H-2 ′ )/75.1, 3.31 (1H, m, H-3 ′ )/78.3, 3.28 (1H, t, J = 8.4 Hz, H-4 ′ )/71.7, 3.21 (1H, m, H-5 ′ )/77.9, and 3.85 (1H, dd, J =12.0, 2.4 Hz, H-6 ′ a), 3.66 (1H, dd, J = 12.0, 6.0 Hz, H-6 ′ b)/62.8, combined with the precolumn derivatization HPLC analysis of acid hydrolysate of 3 (Supplementary Fig. S81), revealed the presence of a β- D-glucopyranosyl moiety in 3 . The HMBC correlation of δ H 3.95 (H-8) with δ C 103.4 (C-1 ′ ) revealed that the glycosidation occurred at the C-8 of the β -patchoulene skeleton in 3 . Thus, the planar structure of 3 was finally elucidated as a previously undescribed 8- O -glucoside derivative of β -patchoulene. The relative configuration of 3 was proposed by analysis of the NOESY data ( Fig. 2 ). NOESY correlations of H 3 -12/H 3 -14 and H 3 -15/H-8 indicated that H 3 -12, H 3 -14, H-15 and H-8 were β -oriented. The absolute configuration of 3 was determined by comparison of its experimental ECD spectra with those calculated by TDDFT method (
). The experimental ECD spectrum of 3 matched well with the simulated one for 4 S ,7 R ,8 S ,10
R -3
( Fig. 4 ). Hence, the absolute configuration of 3 was elucidated as 4 S ,7 R , 8 S ,10 R .
a Measured in CD OD;
c Measured at 150 MHz.

(1 S ,3 R ,5 R ,7 S ,8 R ,9 S )-1-Methoxy-7-(methoxymethyl)-4-methylenehexahydro-3,7-epoxycyclopenta[ c ]pyran-4a,6(1 H )-diol ( 4 ) was afforded as a colorless oil. Its molecular formula was deduced to be C 12 H 18 O 6 with four degrees of unsaturation, based on the analysis of its HRESIMS ([M-H] - m/z 257.1027, calcd 257.1031) and NMR data ( Table 2 ). The NMR data revealed the presence of two methoxyls at δ H / δ C 3.36 (3H, s, H 3 -1 ′′ )/60.0 and 3.37 (3H, s, H 3 -1 ′ )/55.4, three methylenes at δ H / δ C 2.41 (1H, dd, J = 14.4, 7.8 Hz, H-6a), 1.94 (1H, dd, J = 14.4, 3.0 Hz, H-6b)/48.2, 5.23, 5.07 (each olefinic proton singlet, H 2 - 11)/107.5, and 3.60 (2H, s, H 2 -10)/74.4 (an oxygenated methylene), and four methines at δ H / δ C 5.11 (a dioxy substituted methine doublet, J = 3.0 Hz, H-1)/98.5, 5.23 (a dioxy substituted methine singlet, H-3)/ 95.3, 4.83 (an oxygenated methine multiplet, H-7)/75.9, and 2.53 (1H, d, J =3.0 Hz, H-9)/46.9, along with the three quaternary carbons at δ C 154.4 (C-4), 78.1 (C-5) and 84.6 (C-8). Further comprehensive analysis of the 2D NMR data ( Table 2 , Fig. 2 ) of 4 suggested the existence of a monoterpenoid scaffold featuring a 6,7-dioxygenated octahydrocyclopenta[ c ]pyran in 4 , similar as in patriscabrol ( 15 ) (
) and jatamanin F ( 16 ) (
). In HMBC spectrum of 4 , correlations from δ H 5.07 (H-11) to δ C 95.3 (C-3), 78.1 (C-5) and 154.4 (C-4), from δ H 5.23 (H-3) to δ C 98.5 (C-1), 84.6 (C-8) and 154.4 (C-4), from δ H 2.41, 1.94 (H 2 -6) to δ C 78.1 (C-5), 46.9 (C-9) and 154.4(C-4), and from δ H 3.60 (H-10) to δ C 84.6 (C-8) and 75.9 (C-7), indicated the presence of two acetals at C-1 and C-3, and an oxo bridge between C-3 and C-8, and established the parent nucleus of 4 , in which CH 3 -8 was replaced by a methyleneoxyl group, and H-5 was replaced by a hydroxyl group. Further, the HMBC correlations of δ H 3.37 (3H, s, H 3 -1 ′ )/ δ C 98.5 (C-1) and δ H 3.36 (3H, s, H 3 -1 ′′ )/ δ C 74.4 (C-10) indicated that the two methoxyls were positioned at C-1 and C-10 of 4 , respectively. The relative configuration of 4 could be partially indicated by the NOESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ) of H 2 -10/H-1 and H 2 -10/H-9, that H 2 -10, H-1 and H-9 were oriented in the same direction. Finally, the absolute configuration of 4 was determined by comparison of its experimental ECD spectrum with those calculated for 1 S ,3 R ,5 R ,7 S ,8 R ,9
S -4
, 1 R ,3 S ,5 S ,7 R , 8 S ,9
R -4
, 1 S ,3 R ,5 R ,7 R ,8 R ,9
S -4
and 1 R ,3 S ,5 S ,7 S ,8 S ,9
R -4
( Fig. 4 ), and the

experimental ECD curve matched well with the calculated one for 1 S ,3 R , 5 R ,7 S ,8 R ,9
S -4
. Hence, the absolute configuration of 4 was assigned as 1 S ,3 R ,5 R ,7 S ,8 R ,9 S . (5 S ,7 R ,8 S ,9 R )-7-Methyl-4-methyleneoctahydrocyclopenta[ c ]pyran- 6,7-diol ( 5 ) was also obtained as a colorless oil. The molecular formula was established to be C 10 H 16 O 3 with three degrees of unsaturation, by analysis of the HRESIMS ([M+H] + m/z 185.1172, calcd 185.1172) and NMR data of 5 . The NMR data revealed the existence of one methyl at δ H / δ C 1.37 (1H, s, H 3 -10)/25.1, four methylenes at δ H / δ C 3.69 (1H, dd, J = 11.4, 6.6 Hz, H-1a) and 3.55 (1H, dd, J = 11.4, 7.8 Hz,H-1b)/62.3,

4.09 (1H, d, J =13.8 Hz, H-3a) and 4.06 (1H, d, J =13.8 Hz H-3b)/68.4, 2.20 (1H, m, H-6a) and 1.79 (1H, ddd, J =12.0, 8.4, 3.6 Hz, H-6b)/39.2, 5.26 (1H, s, H-11a) and 5.09 (1H, s, H-11b)/114.6, and three methines at δ H / δ C 3.03 (1H, q, J =9.0 Hz, H-5)/42.4, 3.96 (1H, d, J =3.6 Hz, H- 7)/82.2 and 2.23 (1H, m, H-9)/52.5, along with two quaternary carbons at δ C 151.0 (C-4) and 85.3 (C-8). The similar NMR pattern as 4 indicated that 5 contained a similar monoterpenoid scaffold ( viz 6,7-dioxygenated octahydrocyclopenta[ c ]pyran) in its structure, as furtherly confirmed by analysis of the HSQC, 1 H 1 H COSY and HMBC data ( Table 2 , Fig. 2 ). Compared with the NMR data of 4 , the vanishment of characteristic NMR signals of two methoxyls (C-1 ′ and C-1 ′′ ), two acetals (C-1 and C-3), one methyleneoxyl (C-10) and one quaternary carbon (C-5), and the occurrence of one methyl at δ H / δ C 1.37/25.1 (C-10), two methyleneoxyls at δ H / δ C 3.69, 3.55/62.3 (C-1) and 4.09, 4.06/68.4 (C-3), and a methine at δ H / δ C 3.03/42.4 (C-5), afforded the planar structure of 5 as 7- methyl-4-methyleneoctahydrocyclopenta [ c ] pyran-6,7-diol. The relative configuration of 5 was projected by the existence of NOESY correlations of CH 3 -8/H-7, CH 3 -8/H-5 and CH 3 -8/H-9 as shown in Fig. 3 . And similarly, the absolute configuration of 5 was determined by comparison of its experimental ECD spectrum with those calculated ( Fig. 4 ). Finally, the structure of 5 was established as (5 S ,7 R ,8 S ,9 R )-7-methyl-4-methyleneoctahydrocyclopenta [ c ] pyran-6,7-diol.
a Measured in CD OD;
d Measured at 150 MHz.

(4 S ,5 R ,7 S ,8 S ,9 R )-4,7-Dimethyloctahydrocyclopenta [ c ] pyran-6,7- diol ( 6 ) was given as a colorless oil with a molecular formula of C 10 H 18 O 3 (two degrees of unsaturation) deduced by analysis of its HRESIMS ([M+H] + m/z 187.1326, calcd 187.1329) and NMR data ( Table 2 ). In the NMR data of 6 , the vanishment of δ C 175.6 or 179.4 and the presence of two methyleneoxyl signals at δ H 3.62 (1H, dd, J =11.0, 4.2 Hz, H-3a), 3.34 (1H, dd, J =11.0, 7.2 Hz, H-3b)/ δ C 68.9 and δ H 3.82 (1H, dd, J =12.0, 7.2 Hz, H-1a), 3.77 (1H, dd, J =12.0, 5.4 Hz, H-1b)/ δ C 61.9, indicated 6 to be a C-1 (or C-3) reduction product of 16 (or 15 ). NMR data of 6 were similar to those of 5 , with the major existence of a doublet methyl [ δ H 0.90 (3H, d, J =6.6 Hz, H 3 -11)/ δ C 17.5] instead of an olefinic methylene [ δ H 5.26 (1H, s), 5.09 (1H, s)/ δ C 114.6] in 5 . Hence, 6 is a C-4,11 hydrogenation product of 5 , which was also supported by the observable HMBC correlations from H 3 -11 ( δ H 0.93) to C-3 ( δ C 68.9), C-4 ( δ C 38.0) and C-5 ( δ C 41.1). Relative configuration of 6 was assigned using a NOESY experiment, in which NOESY correlations of H 3 -10/H-9, H 3 -10/H-5, and H-4/H-5 indicated H-4, 5, 9, 10 to be oriented in the same direction. Similarly, ECD simulation and comparison were then applied for the investigation of the absolute configuration of 6 , whose structure was finally established to be 4 S ,5 R ,7 S ,8 S ,9
R -6
, with an experimental ECD curve identical with the simulated one by TDDFT method (
).
a Measured at 600 MHz in CD OD;
3 b Measured at 150 MHz in CD OD.

(1 S ,3 S ,4 R ,1 ′ R )-7,7-Dimethyl-3-methylenebicyclo[2.2.1]heptan-2- O - β -D-apiofuranosyl (1→6)- O -β -D-glucopyranoside ( 7 ) was obtained as a colorless oil. Its molecular formula was deduced to be C 21 H 34 O 10 based on the analysis of its HRESIMS ([M-H] - m/z 445.2078, calcd 445.2079) and NMR data ( Table 3 ), representing five degrees of unsaturation. Notably, the sugar NMR data of 7 was identical with those of compound
2 in
the same deuterated solvent (CD 3 OD) ( Tables 1 and 3 ), whose PMP-HPLC analytical result of its acid hydrolysate afforded us final evidence for the absolute configurations of its contained sugars. Hence, the same glycone of β -D-apiofuranosyl-(1 → 6)- β -D-glucopyranosyl as that of 2 (or 17 ) (
), can be deduced to be existed in 7 . In the HMBC spectrum of 7 ( Fig. 2 ), correlations from δ H 1.12 (3H, s, H 3 -9) and 0.97 (3H, s, H 3 -10) to δ C 54.6 (C-1), 51.7 (C-4) and 46.7 (C-7), from δ H 2.06 (1H, d, J = 2.4 Hz, H-1) to δ C 88.0 (C-3), 51.7 and 26.4 (C-5), from δ H 2.09 (1H, d, J =3.0 Hz, H-4) to δ C 54.6, 159.3 (C-2), 88.0 (C-3) and 28.1 (C-6), from δ H 5.13 (1H, t, J =1.5 Hz, H-8a), 5.03 (1H, br s, H-8b) to C-1, C-2 and C-3, and from δ H 3.92 (1H, d, J =1.8 Hz, H-3) to C-1, C-2, C-5, C-7 and C-1’ ( δ C 105.8), afforded the monoterpenoid-type aglycone skeleton of 7 as shown in Fig. 1 . The deduced disaccharide glycone was substituted at C-3 of the skeleton by a HMBC correlation from H-1’ ( δ H 5.13, d, J =2.4 Hz) to C-3. Thus, the planar structure of 7 was characterized as 7,7-dimethyl-3-methylenebicyclo [2.2.1] heptan-2- O -β -D-apiofuranosyl (1 → 6)- O -β -D-glucopyranoside. Unfortunately, owing to the insufficient amount, acid hydrolysis and PMP-HPLC analysis of 7 didn’ t provide us with any direct evidence for settling the absolute configuration of its sugars. Nevertheless, similar as compound 2 , the presence of NOESY correlation between H-2" ( δ H 3.89, d, J =2.4 Hz) and H-4 ′′ b ( δ H 3.95, d, J =9.6 Hz) and the absence of NOESY correlation between H-2 ′′ and H-1" ( δ H 5.01, d, J = 2.1 Hz) ( Fig. 3 ) indicated a β -D-configuration of the apiofuranosyl moiety as reported by Piˇcmanova´ and
and Juliao ˜et al. (2010). And the β -configuration of the glucopyranosyl moiety could be projected by the 3 J coupling constant between H-1 ′ and H-2 ′ , which was above 7.0 Hz. As shown in Fig. 3 , the remaining NOESY data of 7 couldn’ t afford enough NOESY correlations for assigning the global relative configuration of 7 . Alternatively, ECD calculations and comparisons of all the possible isomers of 7 as shown in Supplementary Figs. S76–S77, were conducted to solve the absolute configuration for 7 . The experimental ECD data of 7 was finally identical with those calculated by TDDFT method for 1 S ,3 S ,4 R ,1 ′ R -7_4
. Hence, the absolute configuration of 7 was afforded as 1 S ,3 S ,4 R ,1 ′ R .
a Measured at 600 MHz in CD OD;
3 b Measured at 150 MHz in CD OD.

(3 S ,4 S )-3-Hydroxy-2-methyl-4-(3-oxoprop-1-en-2-yl)cyclopent-1- enecarbaldehyde ( 8 ) was isolated as a colorless oil with molecular formula of C 10 H 12 O 3 deduced from the HRESIMS ([M+H] + ion at m/z 181.0858, calcd 181.0859) and NMR data. NMR spectra ( Table 4 ) of 8 showed signals for a methyl at δ H / δ C 2.25 (3H, s, H 3 -10)/11.5, two aldehyde groups at δ H / δ C 10.05 (1H, s, H-6)/190.3 and 9.59 (1H, s, H 2 - 8)/195.7, two methylenes at δ H / δ C 2.00 (1H, dd, J =7.2, 3.6 Hz, H-5a), 1.97 (1H, dd, J = 9.0, 7.2 Hz, H-5b)/40.6 and 5.99 (2H, d, J = 3.4 Hz, H 2 -9)/133.9, and two methines at δ H / δ C 4.77 (1H, t, J = 7.2 Hz, H-3)/ 80.1 and 3.98 (1H, d, J = 8.1 Hz, H-4)/40.4. Based on the HMBC correlations from δ H 2.00, 1.97 to δ C 138.8 (C-1), 166.7 (C-2), 80.1 (C-3), 40.4 (C-4), and 152.9 (C-7), from δ H 10.05 to δ C 138.8 and 40.6, from δ H 9.59 to δ C 133.9, 152.9 and 40.4, from δ H 5.99 to δ C 40.4, 152.9 and 195.7, and from δ H 2.25 to δ C 138.8, 166.7 and 80.1, the planar structure of 8 was then afforded by assembling the above-mentioned moieties accordingly as shown in Fig. 1 , namely 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4-(3-oxoprop-1-en-2-yl)cyclopent-1-enecarbaldehyde. In 1 H NMR spectrum of 8 , the 3 J coupling constant of H-3 (a methine at δ H 4.77) and H-4 (an oxygenated methine at δ H 3.98) was above 7.0 Hz, indicating that H-3 and H-4 may orient in the opposite direction. Further, ECD calculation and comparison was applied to determine the absolute configuration of 8 , which was then settled to be 3 S , 4 S with its experimental ECD curve identical with the simulated one of 3 S ,4
S -8
.

The molecular formula of 7-(furan-2-yl)-4,7-dioxoheptanoic acid ( 9 ) (a colorless oil) was deduced to be C 11 H 12 O 5 , with six indices of hydrogen deficiency, by analysis of its HRESIMS and NMR data ( Table 5 ). The 1 H NMR signals at δ H 7.75 (1H, s, H-11), 6.63 (1H, dd, J = 3.6, 1.7 Hz, H-10), and 7.34 (1H, dd, J =3.6, 0.6 Hz, H-9), and the 13 C NMR signals at δ C 148.3 (C-11), 113.3 (C-10), 118.8 (C-9), and 153.8 (C- 8), suggested the existence of a furan ring in 9 . The remaining 1 H and 13 C NMR data indicated the presence of three carbonyl carbons at δ C 180.8 (C-1), 211.1(C-4) and 189.9 (C-7), and four methylenes at δ H / δ C : 2.44 (2H, t, J = 7.0 Hz, H 2 -2)/ δ C 32.7, 2.75 (2H, t, J = 7.0 Hz, H 2 -3)/39.9, 3.12 (2H, m, H 2 -5)/33.1, and 2.90 (2H, t, J = 6.4 Hz, H 2 -6)/36.9. The structure of 9 was then established by those HMBC correlations shown in detail in Table 2 and Fig. 2 , as 7-(furan-2-yl)-4, 7-dioxoheptanoic acid.

It has been well-recognized that neuroinflammation is closely related to the progression of neurodegenerative diseases, can drive pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases once it has begun. and microglia are the key cell type in the pathogenesis of neuroinflammation (
). Herein, the activities of those isolates on the viability and the NO production of BV-2 cells upon LPS stimulation, were evaluated for their anti-neuroinflammatory properties ( Fig. 5 ), with minocycline selected as the positive drug. Unfortunately, compounds 4 , 6 , 16 , 18 , 21 , 24 , and 25 were not tested due to their insufficient amounts. As shown in Fig. 5A , all the test compounds except 22 didn’ t exert any significant effects on the cell viability of BV-2 cells, indicating that they didn’ t show any cytotoxicities on BV-2 cells at the concentration of 10 μ M. Finally, the result ( Fig. 5B ) revealed that compounds 3 , 14 , and 20 (10 μ M) significantly inhibited the NO production of LPS-induced BV-2 cells, with inhibition ratios of 71.28 ± 2.46%, 66.75 ± 3.97%, 71.57 ± 2.94%, respectively.

sec.title: Orphanage
4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p:
Optical rotations were measured using a Rudolph AUTOPOL V polarimeter (Rudolph Research Analytical, Hackettstown, USA ). 1D/2D NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV-III spectrometer ( 1 H/ 13 C, 600 MHz/150 MHz, Bruker, Zurich , Switzerland ) using TMS as an internal standard. Chemical shifts ( δ ) were expressed in ppm. HRESIMS spectra were obtained on UPLC-Q Exactive Orbitrap-MS (Thermo Scientific, America). ECD curves spectra were collected by a JASCO-815 ECD spectrometer (JASCO Co., Ltd., Tokyo , Japan ). Preparative HPLC was performed on Prominence LC-20 (SHIMADZU, Japan ) using a preparative Agilent Eclipse XDB-C18 PRETHT column ( 21.2 mm × 250 mm , 7 μ m). Column chromatography (CC) was performed with silica gel (100–200, 200–300, and 300–400 mesh; Qingdao Marine Chemical Inc., China ), ODS (50 μm, YMC, Tokyo , Japan ), Sephadex LH-20 (GE Healthcare Bio-Sciences AB, Sweden ), and D101 macroporous resin ( Tianjin Chemical Co., Ltd., Tianjin , People’ s Republic of China ). Column fractions were monitored by TLC (silica gel 60 GF254, 20 μ m, Merck, Darmstadt, Germany ), and the spots were visualized by heating the plates after spraying with 10% H 2 SO
4 in
ethanol. Standard sugars (Dapiose, D-glucose) for precolumn derivatization HPLC analysis were obtained from Shanghai Yuanye Bio-Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, People’ s Republic of China ). All reagents of HPLC or analytical grade were purchased from Concord Technology ( Tianjin ) Co., Ltd., Tianjin , People’ s Republic of China .

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
The roots and rhizomes of
Valeriana officinalis L
. ( Valerianaceae ) were collected from the West Mountain of Kunming , Yunnan Province , People’ s Republic of China . (GPS N25 ◦ 03 ′ , E102 ◦ 67 ′ ) in
June 2019
. The plant material was authenticated by Prof. Tianxiang Li from the School of Chinese Materia Medica , Tianjin University of Traditional Chinese Medicine , and then subjected to an industrial-grade extraction to afford a standard water decoction extract in Risun Bio-Tech Inc. (http://zh engdong.enviejewel.com/index.php?lang=en), Xi’ an National Economic and Technological Development Zone , Xi’ an, People’ s Republic of China. The specimen ( No. 201907140185) and the water decoction (No. ZDV190418) were deposited at the Institute of Traditional Chinese Medicine , Tianjin University of Traditional Chinese Medicine , Tianjin, People’ s Republic of China
.
4.3. Extraction and isolation

The water decoction (800.0 g) was dissolved with 4.0 L water and extracted with the same volume of EtOAc for three times to obtain the extract ( 8.2 g ). The EtOAc extract was separated by silica gel column (250.0 g) and eluted by CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:0, 50:50, 30:70, 0:100) to obtain 15 components (Fr.1–15). The residual water decoction (786.0 g) was eluted by D101 macroporous adsorbent resin in the water and 95% EtOH to obtain a water-eluted fraction (513.0 g) and 95% EtOH elution fraction ( 111.4 g ). After the pH was adjusted to 4, n -butanol extract ( 7.4 g ) was obtained from 95% EtOH fraction by using n -butanol, and then the n -butanol extract was separated by Sephadex LH-20 gel column chromatography (MeOH–H 2 O 80:20, v / v ) to obtain 11 fractions (Z- 1–11). Fr.3 ( 0.37 g ) was subjected to ODS (CC), eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (30:70–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 19 subfractions (Fr.3.1–Fr.3.19). Fr.3.8 was fractionated by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 49:51, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give 11-methoxyl-viburtinal ( 14, 5.9 mg , t R = 15.0 min). Fr.3.19 was isolated by prep. TLC ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH 30:1, v / v ) to yield 3-acetoxyl-patchouli alcohol ( 1, 1.0 mg, R f = 0.3). Fr.5 ( 2.7 g ) was fractionated by silica gel CC (80.0 g), gradiently eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:0–0:100), which were then combined by checking their TLC and HPLC chromatographic patterns to afford 15 subfractions (Fr.5.1–Fr.5.15). Then, Fr.5.3 ( 0.37 g ) was isolated by ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (70:30–100:0, v / v ) to yield 8-acetoxyl-patchouli alcohol ( 11, 21.2 mg ). Fr.5.4 ( 0.52 g ) was purified by ODS CC, eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (30:70–100:0, v / v ) to yield 1-methoxy-7-(methoxymethyl)- 4-methylenehexahydro-3,7-epoxycyclopenta [ c ] pyran-4a,6(1 H )-diol ( 4 , 1.0 mg). Fr.5.5 ( 0.17 g ) was purified by gradient column chromatography on ODS column (MeOH–H 2 O; 30:70–100:0, v / v ), followed by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 82:18, v / v , 6 ml/min) to afford valeriananoid A ( 12, 4.6 mg , t R =13.0 min). Fr.5.9 ( 0.22 g ) was subjected to gradient column chromatography on ODS column (MeOH–H 2 O; 30:70–100:0, v / v ) to give 8-hydroxyl-patchouli alcohol ( 10 , 12.3 mg ). Fr.5.10 ( 0.36 g ) was purified by gradient column chromatography on ODS column (MeOH–H 2 O; 0:100–100:0, v / v ) to give vanillic acid ( 25 , 3.5 mg ), another followed by prep. TLC ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH 15:1, v / v ) to afford ferulic acid ( 24, 5.7 mg , R f = 0.5). Fr.5.11 ( 0.1 g ) was fractionated by preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O 30:70, v / v , 6 ml/min) to obtain 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4-(3-oxoprop-1-en-2-yl) cyclopent-1-enecarbaldeh yde ( 8, 4.7 mg , t R = 11.5 min). Fr.6 ( 0.4 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (10:90–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 14 subfractions (Fr.6.1–Fr.6.14). Fr.6.8 was fractionated by prep. TLC ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH 13:1, v / v ) to give 7-(furan-2-yl)-4, 7-dioxoheptanoic acid ( 9 , 1.0 mg, R f = 0.3). Fr.8 ( 0.57 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 12 subfractions (Fr.8.1–Fr.8.12). Fr.8.7 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 15:85, v / v , 6 ml/min, t R = 25.8 min), then followed by column chromatography on a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) to afford 4-hydroxybenzoic acid ( 18 , 1.2 mg ). Similarly, Fr.8.10 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 27:73, v / v , 6 ml/min, t R = 19.1 min), then followed by column chromatography on a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) to give 4-hydroxylcinnamic acid ( 19 , 12.0 mg). Fr.9 ( 0.24 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 19 subfractions (Fr.9.1–Fr.9.19). Fr.9.7 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 15:85, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give patriscabrol ( 15 , 5.6 mg , t R = 17.5 min) and Fr.9.7.4 ( t R = 22.0 min). Then, Fr.9.7.4 was purified by column chromatography on a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) to afford jatamanin F ( 16 , 1.0 mg). Fr.10 ( 0.47 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 19 subfractions (Fr.10.1–Fr.10.19). Fr.10.6 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 15:85, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give protocatechuic acid ( 20 , 14.8 mg , t R =16.5 min). Fr.10.11 was fractionated by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 15:85, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give caffeic acid ( 21 , 0.9 mg , t R = 10.6 min). Fr.11 ( 0.64 g ) was chromatographed over a Sephadex LH-20 column, gradiently eluted with MeOH to give 3 fractions (Fr.11.1–Fr.11.3). Fr.11.3 ( 0.25 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–00:0, v / v ) to obtain 4 subfractions (Fr.11.3.1–Fr.11.3.4) and β- patchoulene-8-O-β- D-glucopyranoside ( 3 , 4.1 mg ). Fr.12 ( 0.56 g ) was chromatographed over a Sephadex LH-20 column, gradiently eluted with MeOH to give 5 fractions (Fr.12.1–Fr.12.5). Fr.12.3 ( 55 mg ) was subjected to ODS CC, eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 5 subfractions (Fr.12.3.1, Fr.12.3.4–Fr.12.3.7) and 7-methyl-4-methyleneoctahydrocyclopenta [c] pyran-6,7-diol ( 5 , 1.0 mg) and 4,7-dimethyloctahydrocyclopenta [ c ] pyran-6,7-diol ( 6 , 1.0 mg). Fr.12.3.6 was purified by preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O 20:80, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give valeriananoid F ( 13 , 1.2 mg , t R =21.0 min). Fr.13 ( 0.55 g ) and Fr.14 ( 1.2 g ) were subjected to Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) to obtain fractions, then followed by ODS reversed-phase column ( 2.5 cm i. d. × 45 cm length), eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 4 subfractions (Fr.13.3.1–Fr.13.3.4). Fr.13.3.2 was fractionated by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 33:67, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give 7,7-dimethyl- 3-methylenebicyclo [2.2.1] heptan-2- O -β -D-apiofuranosyl (1 → 6)- Oβ -D-glucopyranoside ( 7 , 1.0 mg, t R = 7.5 min). Z-3 ( 1.55 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v , gradient system) to obtain 9 subfractions (Z-3-1–Z-3-9). Z-3-3 was fractionated by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 35:65, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give patchouli alcohol 8- O -β -D-apiofuranosyl-(1 → 6)- β -D-glucopyranoside ( 2 , 3.0 mg, t R = 7.4 min) and bornyl-6- O -β -D-apiofuranosyl (1 → 6)- β -D-glucopyranoside ( 17 , 1.9 mg , t R = 7.8 min). Z-3-4 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 55:45, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give aurantiamide acetate ( 26 , 2.2 mg , t R = 24.7 min). Z-5 ( 0.56 g ) was subjected to ODS CC, gradiently eluted with gradient MeOH–H 2 O (0:100–100:0, v / v ) to obtain 5 subfractions (Z-5-1–Z-5-5). Z-5-2 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 7:93, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give coniferin ( 23 , 1.0 mg, t R = 11.5 min). Z-7 ( 0.19 g ) was fractionated by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 25:75, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give 5 fractions (Z-7-1–Z-7-5). Then Z-7-5 was purified by preparative HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O 13:87, v / v , 6 ml/min) to give chlorogenic acid ( 22 , 6.0 mg, t R = 9.0 min).

sec.title: 4.4. Acid hydrolysis of compounds 2 and 3
sec.p:
To determine the absolute configuration of monosaccharide constituents of isolated compounds, the method of PMP (1-phenyl-3- methyl-5-pyrazolone)-HPLC analysis upon acid hydrolysis (Fan, et al., 2019) was used. Each solution of 2 and 3 (each 1.0 mg) in 2 M HCl (2 ml) was heated at 90 ◦ C for 3 h. Each solution mixture was then extracted three times with CHCl 3 (2.0 ml). The H 2 O layer was dried in vacuum to produce a mixture of monosaccharides. Sugars of each sample were dissolved in H 2 O (0.5 ml) containing 0.3 M (0.2 ml) NaOH and 0.5 M PMP (0.2 ml) and heated at 70 ◦ C for 0.5 h. 0.3 M HCl (0.2 ml) was added into each reaction mixture, which was then extracted three times with CHCl 3 (1.0 ml) to remove the PMP. The collected supernatants were analyzed by a HPLC system (Agilent 1260 Infinity II) equipped with a PDA detector (detection wavelength: 250 nm ) and a COSMOSIL C 18 column ( 4.6 mm i. d. × 250 mm ) at 35 ◦ C. The solvent gradient was CH 3 CN-0.02 M aqueous ammonium acetate solution (17:83, v/v ) for 50 min at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. The derivatives of monosaccharides D-glucose, D-apiose in 2 and 3 were identified by comparison of their retention times with those of authentic sugars treated in the same way (D-apiose:
tR
41.2 min, D-glucose:
tR
45.7 min).

sec.title: 4.5. ECD calculations
sec.p:
As similar process as our previous study reported (
) relative configuration of 1 , 3–8 was deduced by analysis of 1D and 2D NMR data and Chem3D modeling. Stochastic conformational searches were firstly performed under the MMFF94 force field using CONFLEX 8 software to afford the low energy conformers. By TDDFT method, geometry optimizations and the frequencies pre-calculations for verifying the stabilities of the conformers, were finished by Gaussian 16 package (Revision C.01) at the B3LYP/6–311 +g (2d, p) basis set level in MeOH. Using the optimized conformers, one hundred excitation states at the B3LYP/6–311 +g (2d, p) level with a IEFPCM solvent model in MeOH or Water were calculated for compounds 1 , 3–8 with a half bandwidth of 0.35–0.50 eV, and the calculation results of different conformers were Boltzmann averaged to simulate the ECD spectra after UV correction, which were finally extracted by SpecDis 1.70.1 software.
